header.title: An Enochian Dictionary GMICALZOMA
header.category: Western Esotericism, Enochian Magic, Occultism, Dictionary

central_thesis: This revised Enochian Dictionary, compiled from the original diaries of Dr. John Dee and Sir Edward Kelly, aims to provide a structured understanding and pronunciation guide for the Enochian language. It emphasizes the profound nature of the Enochian system, advocating for respectful and responsible practice, and contextualizing its historical revelation while clarifying misconceptions surrounding Dee and Kelly's work.

structure_content.summary: The introduction details the book's publishing history, the author's deep personal connection to John Dee's work, and the challenges inherent in Enochian studies. It stresses the profound and different nature of Enochia compared to other magical systems, highlighting the need for respect and caution in its application. It also touches on the reprinting history of the dictionary and the author's perspective on the ongoing relevance of Dee's work.

structure_content.chapter_title: Biographical Notes of Dr. John Dee and Sir Edward Kelly.
structure_content.summary: This extensive section provides biographical details for John Dee and Edward Kelly, clarifying historical truths from popular fiction. It outlines Dee's multifaceted career as a scholar, mathematician, and occultist, his vast library, and his role in English exploration. It also covers Kelly's background as Dee's scryer, their collaborative work on angelic magic, their travels, and the controversies they faced, including accusations of sorcery and the infamous 'sharing of wives' incident. The author defends Dee's character and contributions against historical detractors.

This chapter addresses the critical issue of Enochian pronunciation, acknowledging the lack of a universally agreed-upon system. The author discusses the development of a suggested pronunciation method, partly based on the Golden Dawn system, for consistency within a magical school setting. It emphasizes flexibility for individual practitioners and the importance of establishing a consistent approach to avoid linguistic 'chaos.' Examples are provided for breaking down and articulating Enochian words, stressing fluency over rigid spelling.

structure_content.chapter_title: A Brief Summary of the Enochian System
structure_content.summary: This chapter concisely summarizes the core elements of the Enochian magical system as revealed to Dee and Kelly. It details the shewstone as a medium for angelic communication, Archangel Uriel's role in guiding Dee, and the construction of key ritual tools such as the Holy Table, Great Seal (Sigilum Emeth), and lesser seals. It introduces the Four Watchtowers of the Earth and the concept of Enochian Calls or Keys for engaging with the Thirty Aethyrs, noting that some Calls were intentionally given in reverse for safety.

structure_content.chapter_title: Notes on the Arrangement and System of the Work
structure_content.summary: This section explains the editorial methodology used in compiling the dictionary. It clarifies how Enochian-to-English and English-to-Enochian sections are structured, how variant spellings found in Dee's manuscripts are handled (marked with 'or'), and the use of the '⇒' symbol to indicate translations. It also details the author's system for breaking down complex Enochian words for easier understanding and pronunciation, recommending hyphens or underlines to delineate word components within sentences, mirroring Dee's original manuscript practices.

This is the core dictionary content, divided into two main sections: Enochian to English and English to Enochian. It provides comprehensive translations of Enochian words and phrases directly from Dr. John Dee's original diaries, including noted variations and editorial clarifications.
This section presents the visual representation of the Enochian alphabet, crucial for reading and understanding the script of the Angelic Language.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Angelic Calls or Keys and The Thirty Aires of Aeythers
structure_content.summary: This section provides the Enochian text and English translations for the first ten of the nineteen Angelic Calls or Keys, and the specific Call of the Thirty Aethyrs. It also lists the names of the Thirty Aethyrs, explaining how practitioners are to substitute the name of a specific Aethyr into the general Call to engage with it.

key_concepts.definition: The language revealed to Dr. John Dee and Edward Kelly by angels, believed to be the true language of angels or the Language of Creation. It is presented as a complex system with its own grammar and syntax.

A prominent Renaissance scholar, mathematician, astrologer, and occultist (1527-1608) who received and meticulously recorded the Enochian system through scrying sessions. The author presents him as a sincere seeker of knowledge and truth, often misunderstood and maligned.

Dee's primary scryer and collaborator (c.1555-1595), through whom most of the Enochian revelations were received. He is portrayed as possessing genuine 'second sight' but also as having a complex, sometimes manipulative, character.
The system of communication with spiritual entities (angels) through specific rituals, scrying, and the Enochian language. It is considered a distinct and powerful system of occult philosophy.
A convex crystal or 'blackstone' used as a medium for scrying, through which Edward Kelly received visions and transcribed angelic messages. Dee himself received one from Archangel Uriel.

A specially constructed ritual table, painted with primary colors and inscribed with Enochian characters and names, designed by Archangel Uriel's instructions to hold the shewstone and seals during angelic communications.
A nine-inch diameter, 1 1/8 inch thick wax seal, inscribed with names of God and angels, central to the Enochian system's operative magic and placed on the Holy Table.

Four elemental towers and their associated angels, described as sentinels placed by God at the 'extremes of our universe' to 'lock out the Forces of Chaos' and preserve 'the compasse and measure of order.'

Nineteen invocations or ritual texts written in the Enochian language, used to initiate communication with specific angelic hierarchies or to access the Thirty Aethyrs. They are considered very powerful and require respectful handling.

Thirty concentric spheres or 'Airs' representing different levels of consciousness or spiritual density within the Enochian cosmology. They are explored using specific Calls and are a central component of the system.

The method of vocalizing the Enochian language. The book acknowledges the lack of a definitive pronunciation and proposes a system, partly based on the Golden Dawn tradition, emphasizing consistency, fluency, and the importance of the practitioner's 'intent for purpose.'

A detailed record of magical experiments, visions, and studies, considered essential for any practitioner of magic, as exemplified by John Dee's meticulous diaries. The author stresses honesty and privacy in its keeping.

The author's commitment to preserve the integrity of John Dee's original Enochian writings by not altering or adding to them, out of respect for Dee's intentions and the unique nature of the received material.

practical_system.description: The book serves as a practical dictionary and guide to the Enochian language, translating words and phrases from Dr. John Dee's original diaries. It outlines the mechanics of Enochian magic as a system for communicating with angels and exploring spiritual realms (Aethyrs). The operative side emphasizes the correct pronunciation and understanding of Enochian words as 'Words of Power.' The author stresses the importance of consistency in pronunciation, disciplined practice, and maintaining a 'magical diary' for meticulous record-keeping, as demonstrated by John Dee himself. The system requires respect, ethical intent, and a recognition of its profound spiritual implications, warning against misuse or casual experimentation.
tools: Shewstone (crystal) for scrying and receiving visions.
Holy Table, painted with specific colors and inscribed characters, as a ritual altar.
Great Seal (Sigilum Emeth), a wax seal with divine and angelic names, placed centrally on the Holy Table.
Four smaller seals, placed under the legs of the Holy Table.
Magical Diary for recording all experiments, visions, and personal insights.
rituals: Pronouncing Enochian Calls or Keys for communication with angelic hierarchies.
Inserting specific Aethyr names into the Call of the Thirty Aethyrs for targeted exploration of spiritual planes.

relevant_quotes.text: 'It means what it says... when you know what it means.'

I gave John Dee my promise that I would respect his ‘moral copyright’ when I did work on the first edition of the dictionary and that is why nothing was changed for the second edition nor will be any subsequent editions.

It has long been my belief that Enochia extends into high and powerful realms and it is a totally different system from the more commonly known magical systems of occult philosophy used. I cannot stress sufficiently that the system should be treated with respect, and always to exercise the need to avoid the danger of misunderstanding or misusing words.

‘The 4 houses, are the 4 Angels of the Earth, which are the 4 Overseers, and Watch-towers, that the eternal God in his providence hath placed, against the usurping blasphemy, misuse, and stealth of the wicked and great enemy, the Devil. To the intent that being put out to the Earth, his envious will might be bridled, the determinations of God fulfilled, and creatures kept and preserved, within the compasse and measure of order.’
I do not believe that John Dee would attempt to use the material given without having permission to do so through the Enochian Angels and their Creator.

You must make the channel and build up the power to make contact and perhaps hardest of all, for them to be accepted. It is not an automatic outcome, it is not a right that you can demand, only a privilege for which you sue or earn.

The original dictionary was published in 1976 and I got my first copy from John Thorpe of Regency Press at 4.11 p.m. on the 13th of July that year. Though unknown to the people who were involved with the work, this was the time and date that Dr. John Dee was born in 1527 at the village of Mortlake on the Thames near London.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book is highly relevant for serious students and practitioners of Enochian magic and Western Esotericism. It provides a meticulously compiled Enochian Dictionary derived directly from John Dee's original diaries, which is a foundational resource. The extensive biographical notes offer crucial historical context, demystifying Dee and Kelly's lives and work from an occult perspective. The discussion on pronunciation, while acknowledging its speculative nature, offers a practical framework for engagement, making the system more accessible for operative purposes. The author's emphasis on respect, responsibility, and the profound nature of Enochian magic aligns with ethical magical practice and highlights the system's potential for deep spiritual work beyond mere curiosity.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of experienced practitioners and advanced students of Western Esotericism, particularly those specializing in Enochian magic, Hermeticism, and grimoire traditions. Academic researchers in occult studies would also find the historical detail and source-based compilation valuable. While acknowledging the specialist nature, the book's comprehensive approach makes it suitable for individuals committed to rigorous, respectful engagement with complex magical systems, rather than casual readers or beginners seeking introductory material.
